Syllabus

# Syllabus

## MKTG 6051 Marketing Research - Rapid Insights

Sec 001, Spring 2026 A, 2 credit

### Course Instructor

#### Linli Xu

![Linli Xu](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179418/download)Department of Marketing
University of Minnesota, Twin Cities
Carlson School of Management
**Email:** [linlixu@umn.edu](mailto:linlixu@umn.edu)
**Phone**: 612-626-3015
**Office**: 3-209 Carlson School
**Office Hours**: By Appointment

### Teaching Assistant

#### Luqian Sun

**Email:** [sun00680@umn.edu](mailto:sun00680@umn.edu)
**Office**: CSOM 4-269
**Office Hours**: By Appointment

### Course Description, Goals, & Objectives

We will focus on developing rapid and actionable insights. We will do this by learning to form testable hypotheses, collect relevant data quickly, and perform fundamental analytics. Techniques may include qualitative research, survey design, sample design, online data collection, descriptive statistics, and tests for statistical significance. By the end of class, students will be able to provide convincing recommendations for common marketing decisions.

The course is most appropriate for people who focus on marketing strategy and management. It is also appropriate for people whose job functions involve working with market research and analytics professionals, who need to assess the quality of marketing research, and whose job requires them to work with, interpret, and take action based on data.

#### Course Prerequisites

MBA 6210, MBA student, Instructor permission

#### Course Delivery Methodology

Class will involve lectures, discussions, and hands-on projects.

### Course Meeting Information

**Time:** Tuesday/Thursday 9:55am - 11:35am

**Place:** CSOM 1-147

#### Additional Meetings:

* You may need to work with peers on some course projects. The time and place/method of the meeting will be determined by you and your peers.

### Tennessen Warning Notice Pursuant to MN Department of Administration’s Data Practices

To make this class more accessible to all enrolled students, we might record class lectures and discussions.  Since your audio/video may be part of those recordings we are informing you.  Along with the instructor and teaching assistants, these recordings will be shared with only the students enrolled in the class during this semester, in accordance with FERPA regulations.

### Communication and Canvas Notifications

The Canvas Notifications system is the main communication tool we will use for course-relevant announcements. If you have not altered your notification settings, you will receive announcements in your UMN email immediately when they are made. If you have altered these settings, it is highly recommended that you reset "Announcements" back to "Notify immediately" in [your communication settings](https://canvas.umn.edu/profile/communication) as seen below so that you receive notices in a timely manner.
![Notification frequency settings. 4 options: Notify immediately, Daily summary, Weekly summary, Notifications off](https://carlsonschool.umn.edu/sites/carlsonschool.umn.edu/files/announcements_notifications.png)
You may also choose to receive notifications through additional channels including a personal email address or push notifications on your phone if you install the Canvas app. Additional channels can be added through your [Canvas Settings](https://canvas.umn.edu/profile/settings).

### Final Exam

The final project and final project comments will serve as our exam.

### Course Materials

#### Required Course Materials

There are no required textbooks for this class. All materials related to the course will be available on Canvas.

#### Required Computer and Software

Students will need to analyze data using Excel on their own computers. In addition, students will need to install the Microsoft Data Analysis Add-in. Note – this add-in is free and should be available to all students after leaving this class. If you are not familiar with Excel, consider getting some training with this tool. We might use R later in the semester, but no prior coding skills are required.

#### Optional Course Materials

I recommend reading articles and books about decision making and biases because they will help you design persuasive marketing appeals. While academic articles are often more rigorous and detailed than books, popular books are generally more approachable and can synthesize multiple fields of study. Recommended authors include people like Ariely, Gilbert, Gladwell, Griskevicius, Kahneman, and Simonson. If you are looking for a place to start, I recommend *Predictably Irrational* by Dan Ariely.

### Assignments & Grading

#### Grading Criteria

**Quizzes**25%

**Research Exercises**  25%

**Final Project** 30% and **Constructive Reviews** 20%

#### Quizzes

We will have multiple online quizzes throughout the semester which should be completed individually. The goal of these quizzes is to assess your knowledge of the fundamentals of the course. Due dates are posted on Canvas.

#### Group Research Exercises

We will have multiple research exercises throughout the semester. The goal of these exercises is to practice course-related skills in a more real-world setting. Assignments and due dates are posted on Canvas. Your grade will be based on your submission. Groups will submit a research plan.

#### Group Final Project

The final project will be a real-world market research project. You will define and research a marketing problem, propose potential solutions, and execute and evaluate outcomes. Details depend on the project each semester but often involve running qualitative and survey research. Groups will submit a final report and will individually critique one final report.

#### Due Dates and Late Work

Dues dates are listed under Assignments and on the Calendar in Canvas. 

#### Attendance Requirement & Penalties

Students must submit assignments on time.

#### Make-up for Missed Attendance, Assignments, & Exams

Please review the [university policy on make-up work](https://z.umn.edu/policy-makeup_work).

#### AI and ChatGPT

Artificial intelligence (AI) language models, such as ChatGPT, may be used for Research Exercise and the Final Project with appropriate citation, but not for quizzes. If you are in doubt as to whether you are using AI language models appropriately in this course, I encourage you to discuss your situation with me. Citations should be included with your submission and should describe exactly how you use the tool(s) for this course requirement. You are responsible for fact checking statements composed by AI language models.

### Graduate Carlson Grading Guidelines

Carlson School uses a grading policy based upon a class median aggregate GPA. Learn more about the [Carlson Course Grading Policy.](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_graduate_grading)

### Carlson & University Policies

#### Academic Misconduct and Scholastic Dishonesty

The Carlson School defines academic misconduct as any act by a student that misrepresents the student's own academic work or that compromises the academic work of another. Scholastic misconduct includes (but is not limited to) cheating on assignments or examinations, plagiarizing, i.e., misrepresenting as one's own work any work done by another, submitting the same paper, or substantially similar papers, to meet the requirement of more than one course without the approval and consent of the instructors concerned, or sabotaging another's work. Within this general definition, however, instructors determine what constitutes academic misconduct in the courses they teach. Students found guilty of academic misconduct face penalties ranging from lowering of the course grade or awarding a grade of F or N for the entire course, to suspension from the University.

Review the [Student Conduct Code](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_student_conduct_code) and [Student Conduct and Academic Integrity website](https://z.umn.edu/student_conduct_academic_integrity).

If you are interested in learning more about how to cite sources and avoid plagiarism, U of M libraries offers online [tutorials and tools related to citations](https://z.umn.edu/research_citation_tools). You can also visit the [Center for Writing](https://z.umn.edu/center_for_writing) for additional assistance.

#### Accommodations for Students with Disabilities

The University of Minnesota is committed to providing all students equal access to learning opportunities. 
The Disability Resource Center (DRC) is the campus office that works with students who have disabilities to provide and/or arrange reasonable accommodations. Students registered with the DRC, who have a letter requesting accommodations, are encouraged to contact the instructor early in the semester. Students who have, or think they may have, a disability (e.g. psychiatric, attention, learning, vision, hearing, physical, or systemic), are invited to contact the DRC for a confidential discussion at 612-626-1333 (V/TTY) or at [drc@umn.edu](mailto:drc@umn.edu). Additional information is available on the [Disability Resource Center website](https://z.umn.edu/disability_resource_center).

#### Title IX

[Title IX](https://z.umn.edu/title_ix_process) prohibits sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, sexual assault, stalking, and relationship violence, in education.

#### Mental Health and Stress Management

As a student you may experience a range of issues that can cause barriers to learning, such as strained relationships, increased anxiety, alcohol/drug problems, feeling down, difficulty concentrating and/or lack of motivation. These mental health concerns or stressful events may lead to diminished academic performance or reduce a student's ability to participate in daily activities. University of Minnesota services are available to assist you with addressing these and other concerns you may be experiencing. Learn more about the broad range of confidential [mental health services](https://z.umn.edu/mental_health_services) available on campus.

#### Writing Support

As a student, you may experience challenges in your writing. The University of Minnesota has a [student writing support resource](https://z.umn.edu/student_writing_support) to help with your writing.

#### Additional University Policies

1. Grade definitions from the Administrative Policy: [*Grading and Transcripts: Twin Cities, Crookston, Morris, Rochester*](https://z.umn.edu/policy-grading_definitions_transcripts).
2. Scholastic Dishonesty (see Board of Regents Policy: *[Student Conduct Code](https://z.umn.edu/policy-student_conduct_code)* and the Administrative Policy: [*Teaching and Learning: Instructor and Unit Responsibilities: Twin Cities, Morris, Rochester*](https://z.umn.edu/policy-instructor_unit_responsibilities)).
3. Administrative Policy: [*Makeup Work for Legitimate Absences: Twin Cities, Crookston, Morris, Rochester*](https://z.umn.edu/policy-makeup_work)
4. Board of Regents Policy: [*Student Conduct Code*](https://z.umn.edu/policy-student_conduct_code); Administrative Policy: [*Teaching and Learning: Student Responsibilities (Twin Cities, Crookston, Morris, Rochester)*](https://z.umn.edu/policy-student_responsibilities)
5. Board of Regents Policy: *[Sexual Harassment, Sexual Assault, Stalking and Relationship Violence](https://z.umn.edu/policy-sexual_harassment_assault_stalking_relationship_violence)*
6. Board of Regents Policy: *[Equity, Diversity, Equal Employment Opportunity, and Affirmative Action](https://z.umn.edu/policy-equity_diversity_eo_aa)*

text: Test your knowledge of this week's materials. You have 20 minutes to complete the quiz.

Define a problem that is optimally addressed by qualitative research. ***Develop a realistic plan that you will actually execute***. Your plan should include:

* Problem definition
* Explanation why your qualitative technique is optimal to address this problem
* Example of findings or results (e.g., quotes, figures, charts)
* Logistics (execution dates, locations, compensation plan if any, plan for pretesting)
* Appendix with research documents (e.g., screener, discussion guide, any other materials)

You can recruit participants a number of ways. Make sure to justify appropriateness of the sample both for research purposes and practicality.

* Convenience sample - friends/classmates
* Posters - around/off-campus
* Social media advertisement
* Customer observation (store, at home, online)
* etc.

Don't start the quiz until after you've had a chance to review the syllabus and group project guidelines. You'll have 30 minutes to complete the quiz, but you can probably complete it much faster.

## Meet Your Course Team

### Linli Xu

#### Linli Xu Associate Professor - Marketing

---

**Linli Xu** joined the Carlson School of Management, University of Minnesota in 2012 after receiving a PhD from the University of Southern California. Her research interests focus on the advertising and digital platforms and specialize in the automotive markets. Her work has been published in *Marketing Science*, *Management Science*, *Quantitative Marketing and Economics*, and *Journal of Marketing*. Xu was named a Young Scholar by the Marketing Science Institute (MSI) in 2019, a biennial award given to the most promising scholars in marketing and closely related fields whose work suggests they are potential leaders of the next generation of marketing academics. Her research was funded by an MSI grant and Carlson School Dean's Small Research Grant. Linli Xu holds a BA in Economics from Jilin University (China) and an MA in Economics from the University of British Columbia (Canada).

### Next step: Read the course syllabus

The [course syllabus](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/assignments/syllabus "Course Syllabus") will provide you with the course schedule, course objectives, explanations of assignments and assessments, grading policies, and instructor contact information. Please read it carefully. You should have a deep familiarity with the schedule and process of the course.

## Module 01: Overview

### Learning Objectives

* Describe course objectives, expectations and requirements
* Begin thinking about the class project
* Market research process

### To-Do This Module

* + Tuesday

1. 1. Get to know each other
   2. Course introduction
   3. Review information about the class project
      * There are two options - a prepared fictional ice cream client or BYOC (Bring Your Own Client). Let me know within the first week if you're interested in bringing your own client.

## Module 02: Qualitative Research and Survey Research Part I

### Learning Objectives

* Understand the value of doing qualitative research.
* Learn when and how to use observational research, ethnography/netnography, projective techniques, focus groups, and depth interviews.
* When to use survey (quantitative) research

### To-Do This Module

* Tuesday

* + [Intel's Sharp-Eyed\_NYT](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179457?verifier=XDFupBN54rStRjq2TNIIQMLy4DXEzPSRB7IirDnO&wrap=1 "Intel’s Sharp-Eyed Social Scientist - The New York Times.pdf")
  + Ethnography/Netnography
    1. [Ethnography Case Study - IKEA shoppers](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179437?verifier=ICRg8aDbstuAhSl34UfOzlbO2bhwQsmewlzlOa4x "MAPPING PEOPLE_ An Ethnographic Case Study of Ikea Shoppers.mp4")
    2. [Intro to Netnography](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F8axfYomJn4) (Optional: [the article introducing the method](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179439?verifier=PtwldExCFSQhIx8clURimH2jLa9yv314AqoxEILH&wrap=1 "Netnography_Kozinets02.pdf"))
  + [Focus Group Example: Happy Planet](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179442?verifier=IZ33wepvijJv4eoxtLByRhDcKWUukZcw7I7NfMig "HP - Happy Planet - Focus Group.mp4")
  + [Focus Groups versus In-Depth Interviews - GreenBook](https://www.greenbook.org/marketing-research/Focus-Groups-versus-In-Depth-Interviews-1022244)
* Thursday
  + Overview of Survey Research
  + Measurement and Scaling
  + Survey data collection methods

### Additional Resources

* LinkedIn Learning Qualitative Summaries\*
  + [Benefits of Qualitative Research](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/marketing-foundations-qualitative-research/benefits-of-qualitative-research?u=95233017)
  + [Selecting the Right Methodology](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/marketing-foundations-qualitative-research/selecting-the-right-methodology?u=95233017)
  + [Creating a Screener](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/marketing-foundations-qualitative-research/creating-a-screener?u=95233017)
  + [Creating a discussion guide](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/marketing-foundations-qualitative-research-2016/creating-a-discussion-guide?u=95233017)
  + [Asking Questions](https://www.linkedin.com/learning/marketing-foundations-qualitative-research/asking-questions?u=95233017)

\*Free access is available through sources such as local libraries (e.g., Hennepin [LinkedIn Learning for Library](https://www.hclib.org/browse/online-resources/online-resources-container/online-resources-section/online-resources-k-n/linkedin-learning)) and free trials ([linkedin free trials](https://www.linkedin.com/learning)).

* [Zoom AI Transcription and Summaries](https://www.zoom.com/en/ai-assistant/)
* [To Obama With Love, and Hate, and Desperation](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544898/files/58179447?verifier=U2p0izFJEYA4jWCsd8EFnXu9hHMWEBRuySiPpspN&wrap=1 "To Obama With Love, and Hate, and Desperation - The New York Times.pdf") - NYT Magazine
* [Shopper Observation Heat Maps](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NG4lFmSO7VQ)
* [Sample size for qualitative research](https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/QMR-06-2016-0053/full/pdf?title=sample-size-for-qualitative-research)
* [What is Qualitative Research and When Should You Use It?](https://www.qualtrics.com/experience-management/research/qualitative-research/) - Qualtrics
* [Using Zoom Videoconferencing for Qualitative Data Collection: Perceptions and Experiences of Researchers and ParticipantsLinks to an external site.](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335744908_Using_Zoom_Videoconferencing_for_Qualitative_Data_Collection_Perceptions_and_Experiences_of_Researchers_and_Participants) - The International Journal of Qualitative Methods

Syllabus

# Syllabus

## MABA6321 Data Management and Big Data

Spring 2026, 2 credits     Jan 20 -  Mar 16

### Course Instructor

#### Dr. De Liu

![Dr. De Liu
](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544815/files/59047800/preview)

Xian Dong Eric Jing Professor
Department of Information and Decision Sciences
Carlson School of Management
University of Minnesota, Twin Cities

**Slack Chat:  <https://maba6321spring2026.slack.com> (preferred) or****Email**: [deliu@umn.edu](mailto:deliu@umn.edu)
**Office Hours**: The instructor will hold [weekly office hours via Zoom](https://umn.zoom.us/j/95452200895?pwd=CT5aUaS0AVjOaj9TGUuNThuy88AiZw.1) on **Thursdays at 4-5 pm** (US Central Time).

#### TA:  Aditya Bobde

![Aditya Bobde](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544815/files/59047801/preview)

PhD Student, Department of Information and Decision Sciences
Carlson School of Management
University of Minnesota, Twin Cities
**Email**: [bobde002@umn.edu](mailto:bobde002@umn.edu)  or **Slack Chat**:  <https://maba6321spring2026.slack.com>

### Course Description, Goals, & Objectives

Data management is the foundation of data-driven enterprises and a cornerstone for business analytics. Organizations store most of their data in a *relational* format. Structured Query Language (SQL), the language for querying and manipulating relational databases, is one of the most important skills for data scientists. Moreover, organizations need to scale their data infrastructure to harness big data, including using parallel processing and cloud computing. Through this course, students will gain competence in practical database, data warehousing, and data management skills with emphasis on query, data modeling, and data management. Students will also be exposed to recent advances in big data technologies and cloud-based data warehousing.

#### Course Prerequisites

* This course has no prerequisites.

#### Course Delivery Methodology

* This course is offered in an **online asynchronous** format via Canvas, allowing students to access pre-recorded lectures, complete assignments and labs, and take quizzes according to their own pace.
* While there are **no required meetings**, students are responsible for adhering to the weekly schedule and actively participating in course activities to remain on track.

#### Course Meeting Information

* As an asynchronous online course, there is no designated meeting times for this course.

### Textbook & Reading Materials

There is no required textbook for this course.

#### Optional Course Materials

* **SQL Queries for Mere Mortals: A Hands-On Guide to Data Manipulation in SQL:** For most students, my notes on SQL would be sufficient. This book is recommended for ones who need a reference book for SQL.

#### Computing Environment

* **MySQL Community Server:**This is the database software that you should install on your computer.
* **MySQL Workbench**: This is the official MySQL GUI client that should be installed on your computer.
* **Databricks Free Edition**: This is the free-to-use cloud service offered by Databricks that we will use briefly for the Big Data module. [Sign up here](https://www.databricks.com/learn/free-edition) (make sure you don't provide any credit card, if you're asked for it, then you may somehow chose to sign up for a regular account).
* **Snowflake**: We may provide a Snowflake computing environment cloud-based data warehousing.

#### Installations Instructions

* Windows: You may install **MySQL Community Server** (8.0.4) and **MySQL Workbench** (8.0.4) by following [this YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C8cLGUuGsrQ).
* Mac: You may install **MySQL Community Server** (8.0.4) and **MySQL Workbench** (8.0.4) by following [this YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-wpzS5NcYT8).

### Assignments & Grading

#### Grading Criteria

Your grade will be based on the following activities:

| Activity | Grade % |
| --- | --- |
| Homework Assignments | 20% |
| Labs | 30% |
| Quiz 1 (Modules 1-3) | 20% |
| Quiz 2 (Modules 4-5) | 15% |
| Quiz 3 (Modules 6-7) | 15% |

#### Grading Scheme

A final letter grade is given according to the following scale.

| Percent | Grade |
| --- | --- |
| 93.0 or above | A |
| 90.0 - 92.9 | A- |
| 87.0 - 89.9 | B+ |
| 83.0 - 86.9 | B |
| 80.0 - 82.9 | B- |
| 77.0 - 79.9 | C+ |
| 73.0 - 76.9 | C |
| 70.0 - 72.9 | C- |
| 60.0 - 69.9 | D |
| Below 60.0 | F |

Though it rarely happens, this scale may be adjusted to ensure compliance with Carlson grading policies, which require a class median GPA of 3.3 +/- 0.2. Learn more about the [Carlson Course Grading Policy](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_graduate_grading).

#### Flex Days for Late Homework Assignments/Labs

**You have 5 flex days** that you may use at your discretion to defer the due date of a **homework assignment** or a **lab**. You must use your flex days in the whole day (24 hours) increments. You can defer a single assignment by **a maximum of 2 days**.

You **do not need to notify the instructor** if you want to use your flex days on a homework or a lab. Submit your homework/lab when ready and the proper number of flex days will be deducted. If you do not want to use your flex days on a certain assignment, please let the instructor know.

Flex days are intended to be used for unforeseen circumstances such as technical difficulties, family emergencies, and personal illness. **After your flex days have been used for the semester, late work will not be accepted and will earn no credit (0 points)**. Additional accommodations must be obtained in advance.

#### Quizzes Format and Proctoring

All quizzes will be conducted on Canvas and will consist of multiple-choice and/or short answers. There will not be hands-on SQL scripting.

This course will use HonorCode to remotely proctor quizzes to ensure integrity and equity in knowledge assessments for all students. HonorLock is easy-to-use, scalable, privacy-focused, and FERPA-compliant. Visit the [University’s site on HonorLock.](https://z.umn.edu/proctorio-student_guide)

#### Late and/or Missed Quizzes

You should complete the quizzes by their designated due dates. If you cannot take a quiz by its due date for any reason, you should alert the instructor in advance and as soon as possible to avoid a zero grade on the quizzes. We generally follow the University policy in approving exam-related accommodations. Please review the [university policy on Excused Absences and Make-up work](https://z.umn.edu/policy-makeup_work).

#### **SmartPAL Participation Extra Credit (1%)**

We have integrated a learning support tool called **SmartPAL** into the course. The tool, created by Professor De Liu from Information and Decision Sciences, aims to boost student support and enhance engagement. It has a built-in chatbot that can answer course-related questions and send personalized reminders, and feedback, while also having some gamification features to keep you motivated. SmartPAL also asks you to complete weekly learning reflections.  We encourage you to try it out, but the usage of the tool is entirely voluntary.  For any assistance related to SmartPAL, please ask its chatbot or reach out to: [support@smartpal.org](mailto:support@smartpal.org).

### Communication

We will use a Slack Workspace **([https://maba6321spring2026.slack.com](https://maba6321spring2026.slack.com/))** for community-based interaction and day-to-day Q&A & support. We recommend that you install it on your mobile device and/or connect with the class community.

We will also use **Canvas** Announcements for official announcements. It is highly recommended that you set "Announcements" delivery to **"Notify immediately"** in [your communication settings](https://canvas.umn.edu/profile/communication).  You may reach the instructor/TA via Slack or Email.

### Academic Integrity

#### Integrity Related to Homework Assignments

I expect you to do all homework assignments **individually**. You may still discuss homework problems with fellow students, but  **no documents or fragments of homework should be shared between students, physically or digitally**. A rule of thumb is that you should have "typed it with your own hands". In case of difficulty, please reach out to the instructor as early as possible.

You should always save a copy of your submitted work, including lab and homework assignments. Store the copy in a secure location (such as your Google Drive).

#### Generative AI Policy

Generative AI (Gen AI) tools, such as ChatGPT and Copilot, can be valuable resources for enhancing your learning experience.  However, their use must align with the following guidelines to maintain academic integrity and ensure meaningful learning:

You are encouraged to use Gen AI for **non-quiz assignments**, including **homework assignments, lab problems, and knowledge check questions**.You may use generative AI to explore ideas, clarify concepts, get hints, and receive help on specific tasks.

The use of Gen AI is **strictly forbidden during quizzes**. Using Gen AI during quizzes is considered a breach of academic integrity and may result in grading penalty and disciplinary actions.

We expect you to use Gen AI responsibly, including

* Always **verify and refine** the generated content to ensure its accuracy and alignment with the course.
* You should **take time to understand generative AI output** and be ready to explain it in your own words.
* You should **incorporate your own ideas and perspectives** instead of relying entirely on generative AI.

It is important that every student should complete the SRT evaluation and provide feedback to the instructor. You evaluation and feedback are always appreciated by the instructor.

### Carlson & University Policies

#### Student Academic Misconduct and Scholastic Dishonesty

The Carlson School defines academic misconduct as any act by a student that misrepresents the student's own academic work or that compromises the academic work of another. Scholastic misconduct includes (but is not limited to) cheating on assignments or examinations, plagiarizing, i.e., misrepresenting as one's own work any work done by another, submitting the same paper, or substantially similar papers, to meet the requirement of more than one course without the approval and consent of the instructors concerned, or sabotaging another's work. Within this general definition, however, instructors determine what constitutes academic misconduct in the courses they teach. Students found guilty of academic misconduct face penalties ranging from lowering of the course grade or awarding a grade of F or N for the entire course, to suspension from the University.

Review the [Student Conduct Code](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_student_conduct_code) and [Student Conduct and Academic Integrity website](https://z.umn.edu/student_conduct_academic_integrity).

If you are interested in learning more about how to cite sources and avoid plagiarism, U of M libraries offers online [tutorials and tools related to citations](https://z.umn.edu/research_citation_tools). You can also visit the [Center for Writing](https://z.umn.edu/center_for_writing) for additional assistance.

#### Accommodations for Students with Disabilities

The University of Minnesota is committed to providing all students equal access to learning opportunities. 
The Disability Resource Center (DRC) is the campus office that works with students who have disabilities to provide and/or arrange reasonable accommodations. Students registered with the DRC, who have a letter requesting accommodations, are encouraged to contact the instructor early in the semester. Students who have, or think they may have, a disability (e.g. psychiatric, attention, learning, vision, hearing, physical, or systemic), are invited to contact the DRC for a confidential discussion at 612-626-1333 (V/TTY) or at [drc@umn.edu](mailto:drc@umn.edu). Additional information is available on the [Disability Resource Center website](https://z.umn.edu/disability_resource_center).

[Title IX](https://z.umn.edu/title_ix_process) prohibits sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, sexual assault, stalking, and relationship violence, in education.

#### Students with Mental Health and Stress Management

As a student you may experience a range of issues that can cause barriers to learning, such as strained relationships, increased anxiety, alcohol/drug problems, feeling down, difficulty concentrating and/or lack of motivation. These mental health concerns or stressful events may lead to diminished academic performance or reduce a student's ability to participate in daily activities. University of Minnesota services are available to assist you with addressing these and other concerns you may be experiencing. Learn more about the broad range of confidential [mental health services](https://z.umn.edu/mental_health_services) available on campus.

## Homework 3 – ER Diagram and Normalizatio

Questions 1-5 and Question 8 are covered in Module 4; The remaining question are covered in Module 5.

* Please answers all questions except question 8 in a single document (word or Google doc).
* For the question 8, please export your MySQL workbench EER diagram as a PDF file and submit it along with your document for other questions.

## Part 1: short answers

For questions 1-5, explain the following concepts **and give an example**.

1. Composite attribute
2. Multi-valued attribute
3. Cardinality of a relationship;
4. One-to-many relationship
5. Many-to-many relationship

For questions 6-7, answer the question

6. What are the main benefits of normalization?
7. When should one consider denormalization?

## Part 2. ER Modeling / Normalization

### 8. Lucy's Play School

Lucy's Playschool is a child day care center. The play school keeps track of each child's contact person, anergies, and rooms they are assigned to, and employees who work in these rooms.

* For each child, it tracks information including name, age, gender, birthday, and allergies. You may treat allergies as a single atomic field.
* Each child must have an adult contact person. It saves information including the contact person's contact phone number, and address (including street, city, state, and zip code). Each child has one adult as his/her contact person but an adult can be a contact person for multiple children (e.g. one family may enroll multiple kids in the center).
* The center has several rooms of different sizes. Each room has a room number, a designated capacity, and an assigned age group (infant, toddler, kid, pre-teen). For example, rooms 2 and 3 are for infants and room 4 is for toddlers.
* A child is assigned to a room based on his/her age and availability of space. Each child is assigned to one room. Each room may be assigned to multiple children. But the room may also be vacant (when the enrollment is low).
* A room may be managed by one or more employees. An employee can manage at most one room. Some employees do not manage any room (e.g. the reception desk employee).
* The center keeps track of each employee's name, phone number, education, and gender

Based on the above description, Develop an ER Diagram for Lucy's Play School using MySQL workbench.

* You may ignore the data types for now.
* If you make any assumptions, please state them explicitly.

### 9. Movie Recommendation System

Imagine you are given a denormalized movie rating table that captures every detail in one place. Please transform the table into a database design that satisfies the 3rd normal form.

* Please do so step by step - first check and satisfy the 1st normal form, then the 2nd normal form, and the third normal form.
* Please give each table an appropriate name that reflects its granularity and content.
* Please also mark each table's primary key fields with PK (or bold or underline).

**MovieRatings** (user\_id, user\_name, user\_age, movie\_id, movie\_title, movie\_genre,director\_id, director\_name, rating, rating\_timestamp)

# MABA 6321 Lab 4: Modeling Data with ER Diagrams

In this lab, we will practice creating ER diagram using MySQL Workbench, as well as identifying entities, attributes, and relationships based on the given business description.

### 1. Consulting contracts

Create an ER diagram using **MySQL Workbench** based on the following description.

* The `consulting contracts` database has three entities: `consultants`, `companies`, and `contracts`.
* `Consultants` has three attributes: `consultant_id`, `consultant_name`, and `specialties`, where `consultant_id` is its primary key (PK).
* `Companies` has three attributes also: `company_id`, `company_name`, and `industry_type`, where the first one is the PK.
* `Contracts` has six attributes:`contract_id`, `company_id`, `consultant_id`, `contract_date`, `hourly_rate`, and `hours`, where the first one is the PK, and the second and third are PKs.

You may assume that all relationships are mandatory on both sides.

### 2. Sports Goods

The Sports Goods sales system maintains detailed records of employees, customers, orders, and products.

* For each customer, it maintains information such as name, address, city, state, zip code, and phone number. Each customer is uniquely identified by a CustomerID.
* Each order is uniquely identified by an OrderNo and includes the order date and total amount. Every order is associated with exactly one customer and one employee, indicating who placed the order and who handled it. The employees involved in the sales process are identified by an EmployeeID and have attributes such as first name, last name, and job title.
* Each order may include multiple products. For each product in an order, the system captures the quantity and purchase price. Each product is identified by a ProdID and includes descriptive attributes such as product name, group (or category), wholesale and retail prices, and the number of units currently on hand.

Create an ER diagram using **MySQL Workbench** based on the above business requirements. If you identify a many-to-many relationship, please convert it to a one-to-many relationships with an associative entity.

### 3. **Fraud Detection**

You are tasked with designing the database for a digital financial services platform that provides online payment and transaction services to a growing user base. The platform allows users to register accounts, log in from different devices, make financial transactions, and make payments using various methods. A critical business requirement is the ability to monitor user activity for fraud detection and generate appropriate reports for high-risk transactions.

Each user on the platform has a unique identifier and associated metadata, such as the date the account was created, the most recent login date, the current account status, and a cumulative count of past transactions. The platform supports device-based logins, meaning that users may interact with the platform using one or more devices, each uniquely identified by a device ID and specified by device type and MAC address.

All transactions are tracked with detailed logs that include the user involved, the transaction amount, the type of transaction (e.g., deposit, withdrawal, purchase), the date, and the device and IP address from which it was made. Additional metadata such as geolocation and number of login attempts at the time of the transaction are also captured. This data is crucial for behavioral analysis and anomaly detection.

To mitigate financial risks, the system includes a fraud detection component. When a suspicious transaction is identified, it is logged in a fraud report, which records the type of fraud, a risk score, and the current resolution status. Each fraud report is linked to both the transaction in question and the user associated with it. This allows the platform to analyze fraudulent behavior across different users and transactions for audit or enforcement actions.

Finally, the platform tracks payments made by users. A user may have multiple payment records, each specifying the payment amount, payment method (e.g., credit card, PayPal), the last four digits of a payment card, and the payment status (e.g., successful, failed, pending). These records are used to manage and reconcile financial flows, support refunds, and maintain compliance with industry standards for transaction processing.

Create an ER diagram using **MySQL Workbench** based on the above business requirements. If you identify a many-to-many relationship, please convert it to a one-to-many relationships with an associative entity.

---

#### Submission guidelines

* submit the PDFs for ER diagrams, one for each ERD.

## Homework 1 – Relational Database and SQL

This homework assignments cover the topics in Module 1 and Module 2, with a focus on relational database concepts and basic to intermediate SQL queries, including summary queries, inner joins, and outer joins. The homework has two parts, Part 1 short answers and Part 2 hands on.

We advise you to complete **lab 1** and **lab 2** before attempting the homework assignments.

If you want, hands on questions 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, 9, and 10 can be completed after learning module 1.

The **solution** to the homework assignment will be published two days after its deadline.

# MABA 6321 Lab 5 - Normalization and DB design

[sportsGoods.mwb](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544815/files/58502053?verifier=zt5LN6S2P4KstNvZMNxbgaixfJTNiZQHbGvbbn4M&wrap=1 "Link")

In this lab, we will focus on normalization and MySQL database design.

* It is recommended that you create a single google doc to hold answers for all three questions.

## Part 1: Normalization

For each problem below, transform the table(s) into a database design that satisfieds the 3rd normal form.

* Do so step by step - first check and satisfy the 1st normal form, then the 2nd normal form, and the third normal form.
* Please give each table an appropriate name that reflects its granularity and content.
* Please also mark each table's primary key fields with PK (or bold or underline).

### 1. employee training courses

In this example, we consider a business scenario where a corporation tracks employee participation in professional training courses. Originally, all the information is stored in one table, which leads to data redundancy and update anomalies. The initial table looks like this:

* **EmployeeTraining** (emp\_id, name, dept, salary, training\_course\_id, training\_date)

### 2. Online Retails Sales

Imagine you’re working with an e-commerce dataset that tracks sales transactions. The initial design is a single large table with order details, customer information, and product data, which leads to redundancy and potential data anomalies.

* **SalesData** (order\_id, order\_date, customer\_id, customer\_name, email, shipping\_address, product\_id, product\_name, unit\_price, quantity)

## Part 2. MySQL Database creation

### 3. Create a `SportsGoods` database

`sportsgood.mdb` is the MySQL workbench EER diagram we have created in the previous week. In this lab problem, we are going to create a database based on the EER model. We will then use generative AI (e.g. ChatGPT) to generate sample data and populate the database. Finally we will verify our database by creating a multi-table query.

* `sportsgood.mwb` was created with out much regard to the field data type. We now want to make these improvements before creating the database.

  + All the financial fields should use a `decimal(10,2)` data type.
  + Some fields should be integeter type (e.g. zip code, prodID, Onhands)
  + Data/Datetime fields should have `date` and `datetime` data types, respectively.
  + The database (schema) should be called `sportsgoods` instead of the default `mydb` (you can change it on the left panel, **Catalog Tree**).
  + Add a comment to the `onHand` field "Number of units on hand" (later on, this provide a hint to ChatGPT what this field is about; other fields are self-explanatory)
* Using **File**> **Export**> **Foreward Engeer SQL create script** to create and save an SQL script for table and database creation. Note that in the last step, you can use **save to Other file** to save the generated script to `sportsgoods.sql`.
* Execute `sportsgoods.sql` in MySQL workbench to create the database and tables.
* Using **GenAI** (e.g. **Copilot** or **ChatGPT**, free version is fine) to generate the insert data scripts. One prompt could be:

  + *I am going to provide a MySQL database creation script. Can you generate corresponding sample data for each table in the form of insert into SQL statements. Make sure the referential integration of the database is respected.*
  + Then, you can paste the sportsgoods.sql into the chatbot, when prompted.
  + Copy the resulting SQL insert scripts to a SQL file, and execute it to populated the database.
* Test your database with a multi-table query that select all tables and fields (with appropriate join conditions).

  + **Tip**: watch out for duplicate column names.

---

**Submission guidelines**:

* For the first two questions.

  + Type out the appropriate steps and resultant tables in each step, making sure the primary key for each table is properly identified.
* For the 3rd question,

  + paste the **dataqbase table creation** script,
  + the **insert into** scripts,
  + and the **query script and results**.

text:
## Overview of The SmartPAL Project

The **SmartPAL project** is an instructional initiative led by Professor De Liu, aimed at promoting self-regulated learning through a combination of chatbots and gamification. SmartPAL leverages generative AI and Canvas integration to give you personalized, context-aware responses and proactive personalized support. The project also empowers instructors by providing data-driven insights and tools to better support students.

## Eligibility

SmartPAL currently works with selected Canvas courses, whose instructors have consented to enable SmartPAL for their courses. Every student in such participating courses can leverage SmartPAL as they progress through the course.

## SmartPAL App Activation

SmartPAL offers both a mobile app and a web app, accessible through a web browser. The web app does not require installation. We encourage you to install the mobile app because you can access it without using a PC.

### SmartPAL Mobile App Installation

Search 'SmartPAL' in the iOS App Store or Google Play Store and look for the owl icon wearing an academic cap to install the app.

If you have downloaded the app in a prior semester, please **check for any available update**, as older version of the App may not work well with newly enrolled courses.

### Sign In

Sign in with your **University email** or **SSO (Single Sign ON)** credentials. If using your email, create a user account the first time you log in.

After signing in, the app will display a list of participating courses you're enrolled in for the current semester. If no courses appear, it may be because (a) you're not enrolled in any participating course, or (b) your enrollment hasn't been synced with SmartPAL. If the issue persists, please contact SmartPAL support at **smartpal@umn.edu**.

On the mobile app, it will also ask you to enable *push notification*. We encourage you to **enable push notification** so that you will always keep updated.

## Earn Extra Credits

Participation in SmartPAL is voluntary. We offer 10.0 points (1.0%) as extra credit for participating in SmartPAL as an instructional tool.

SmartPAL participation accounts for 10.0 points (1.0%) extra credit. To secure the extra credit, please complete the following tasks:

* **SmartPAL Post Survey** (0 points): Complete a post survey near the *end of the course*. The link to the survey is available through the `SmartPAL Post Survey` assignment.
* **SmartPAL App Activation** (0.0 points): Install/Activate the SmartPAL app at the beginning of the course. The instruction is given via the `SmartPAL App Activation` assignment.
* **SmartPAL Learning Engagement** (5.0 points): Earn **42 learning engagement gems** by the end of the course to receive the full credit on this assignment. See `SmartPAL Learning Engagement` assignment for more details.
* **SmartPAL Reflections** (5.0 points): Complete **5 reflections** by the end of the course to receive the full credit on this assignment. See the `SmartPAL Reflections` assignment for more details.

## Why should you participate in the SmartPAL project?

* SmartPAL will help you stay on top of your course and realize your full learning potential.
* You'll gain first-hand experience with innovative AI learning assistant technologies through SmartPAL.
* Your insights and feedback help improve SmartPAL as an instructional tool, enhancing the learning experience for you and future students.

## Earning Gems for Learning Engagement

The app uses gems as a fun way to track your engagement in the course. You can collect gems from four types of engagement activities:

* **Canvas Pageviews**: Each week, you can earn gems for being an active user of Canvas. A *pageview* means each time you click a Canvas link (such as an assignment, announcement, module, quiz). We track the number of pageviews you generate in the course and award gems based on the following rubric.:
  + 1 to 10 pageviews, you will receive 1 gem
  + 10 to 100 pageviews, you will receive 2 gems
  + 100+ page views, you will receive 3 gems
* **On-time Assignment Submissions**: You can earn gems each week by submitting assignments on time. For eligible assignments with due dates, gems are awarded based on the following rubric:
  + missed all assignments, you earn 0 gems.
  + Submitted at least one assignment (late or on time), 1 gem
  + Submitted an assignment on time, 2 gems.
  + Submitted all assignments on time, 3 gems.
  + No assignments that week, you automatically earn 3 gems.
* **Learning Reflections**: SmartPAL asks you to reflect on your learning every week.
  + Completing this week's reflection earns you 2 gems.
* **SmartPAL Engagement**: SmartPAL Engagement reflects how often you interact with the SmartPAL app. Each week, we measure engagement by counting the number of days you use the app. Based on this, you'll earn gems according to the following rubric.:
  + Using SmartPAL (mobile or web) on 1 day during the week earns you 1 gem.
  + Using SmartPAL (mobile or web) on 2 days during the week earns you 2 gems.
  + Using SmartPAL (mobile or web) on 3+ days during the week earns you 3 gems.

## Using Weekly Reflections to Enhance Your Learning and Instruction

Each week, SmartPAL will ask you to complete a quick reflection on your learning—what worked well and what was challenging. It only takes a few minutes and helps both you and your instructor improve your learning experience. You can earn gems by completing learning reflections as part of your SmartPAL Learning Engagement.

Complete your weekly reflections on the Mobile or Web App.

## Level Up

Earning gems helps you level up—your level rises after you've accumulated enough gems. We use the following rules to determine your level:

* Level 1 (Noob): 0-17 gems
* Level 2 (Pro): 18-47 gems
* Level 3 (Epic): >= 48 gems

## Leaderboard

We publish two leaderboards to celebrate the most engaged students in the course:

* **Weekly leaderboard**: based on the number of gems earned in the current week (starting from Sunday)
* **All-time leaderboard**: based on the total number of gems earned since the beginning of the course.

The leaderboard size is fixed at 5. If there is a tie (two or more students with the same number of gems), we include the one who has the most Canvas pageviews.

## How to use the SmartPAL Chatbot?

The built-in Chatbot uses generative AI to understand and answer questions. The chatbot can currently answer the following types of questions:

* Syllabus questions: e.g., what is the late policy?
* Logistics and planning questions: e.g., What is covered in quiz 2? What is planned for this week? What are latest announcements?
* Assignment questions: e.g. when is test X? what is my grade for the group project?
* Grading related questions: e.g. What is my grade for test X? what is my grade for the group project?
* SmartPAL related questions: e.g., How do I get engagement score on this app? How do I get more gems?
* Questions related to the course topics: Can you explain the concept of \_\_\_?

As this is a prototype chatbot, some responses may be incomplete or inaccurate. We appreciate your patience and understanding as it develops.

## How do I get help or report a problem?

You may report SmartPAL problems or ask questions by emailing **smartpal@umn.edu**. We will get back to you as soon as possible, usually within 24 hours.

## Module 05: Overview

This module introduces the normalization principle for minimizing data redundancy and ensuring data consistency. The normalization principles (or norms) helps you understand why, and how, to structure your data for different applications. This module also introduces practical relational database design using MySQL workbench.

### Learning Objectives

* Explain the purpose and benefits of database normalization
* Identify data anomalies caused by poor database design
* Understand and apply normal forms to structure relational data
* Analyze functional dependencies to guide normalization
* Evaluate when to normalize vs. denormalize
* Use MySQL Workbench to create a database

### To-Do This Module

* Watch lecture videos and related supportive content
* Complete **knowledge checks** associated with each video (if available)
* Complete the **lab 5**for the module
* Complete **homework 3**.
* Take the **Quiz 2**.

## Module 01: Overview

In this first module, you will embark on a comprehensive journey into the world of databases and SQL. The module begins with an overview of the syllabus and course setup, ensuring you are well-prepared for the learning ahead. An introduction to databases will lay the foundation, covering basic relational database concepts essential for data management and analysis. Next, we will explore the history and characteristics of SQL, gaining insights into its pivotal role in data querying and manipulation. Practical skills will be developed through writing single table queries using WHERE and ORDER BY clauses, as well as executing data manipulation statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE. This module aims to equip you with the foundational skills necessary for effective database interaction and data analysis.

### Learning Objective

1. Review basic relational database concepts.
2. Describe the history and characteristics of SQL.
3. Construct single table queries using WHERE and ORDER BY clauses.
4. Execute data manipulation statements, including INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE.

### To-Do This Module

* Watch lecture videos and related supportive content
* Complete **knowledge checks** associated with each video (if available)
* Install **MySQL Server & MySQL Workbench** if you have not already (see instructions in [Syllabus](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544815/assignments/syllabus "Syllabus"))
* Install databases including **invoices**, **department**, **classicmodels**, and **pets\_stackexchange** (see [Datasets](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/544815/pages/datasets "Datasets"))
* Complete the **lab 1** for the module
* You may complete the **part of homework 1** covered in this module, or wait till Module 2 to this homework.

## Course Overview

## Meet Your Instructor

### Dr. De Liu

#### **photo of Dr. De Liu**

**Xian Dong Eric Jing Professor, Information and Decision Sciences**

---

Dr. De Liu is a Xian Dong Eric Jing Professor of Information and Decision Sciences at the Carlson School of Management, University of Minnesota. He received his Ph.D. from the University of Texas at Austin, and his Master's and Bachelor's degrees from Tsinghua University. His recent research interests include gamification, Internet-based auctions and market mechanisms, crowdfunding, and AI /Augmented Reality applications. His research has appeared in leading journals such as MIS Quarterly, Management Science, Information Systems Research, Journal of Marketing, Journal of Market Research, and Production and Operations Management. He previously served as an associate editor for Information Systems Research and Journal of Organizational Computing and Electronic Commerce.

## Module 02: Overview

In this module, we will continue our journey on SQL and relational database. You will learn how to write **summary queries** using aggregate functions such as `SUM`, `AVG`, `COUNT`, `MIN`, and `MAX` to extract insights from datasets. We will also explore a variety of **SQL functions** that help you manipulate and analyze **numeric**, **textual**, and **datetime** values effectively. Additionally, this module will introduce the concept of **joining multiple tables** to answer more complex questions that require data from different sources. You’ll work with **inner joins**, **outer joins**, and understand how to combine data from related tables based on key relationships.

### Learning Objectives

* Write summary queries using aggregation functions and GROUP BY
* Create computed columns using SQL functions and expressions
* Query multiple tables using inner, outer joins, and union

UPDATE vendors
SET vendor_address2 = ""

UPDATE vendors

# MABA 6321 Homework 2 - Advanced SQL

### 1. Find the information on `employees` who have other employees reporting to them and show their employee number, last name, first name,, extension, and job title. Make sure the output does not have duplicate rows.

```
SELECT employeeNumber, lastName, firstName, extension, jobTitle
FROM employees
WHERE employeeNumber IN
(SELECT DISTINCT reportsTo FROM employees);

-- 6 row(s) returned

-- # employeeNumber, lastName, firstName, extension, jobTitle
-- 1002, Murphy, Diane, x5800, President
-- 1056, Patterson, Mary, x4611, VP Sales
-- 1143, Bow, Anthony, x5428, Sales Manager (NA)
-- 1102, Bondur, Gerard, x5408, Sale Manager (EMEA)
-- 1088, Patterson, William, x4871, Sales Manager (APAC)
-- 1621, Nishi, Mami, x101, Sales Rep
```

### 2. Using a sub query to find the largest order quantity per order for each product, displaying the product's code, largest order quantity (as `largest_order_quantity`), ordering results from the highest to the lowest.

```
SELECT  distinct p.productCode, p.productName, o.quantityOrdered AS largest_order_quantity
FROM orderdetails AS o JOIN products AS p
USING (productcode)
WHERE o.quantityOrdered = (
    SELECT max(quantityOrdered)
    FROM orderdetails
    WHERE productcode  = o.productCode
)
ORDER BY o.quantityOrdered desc;

-- 109 row(s) returned

-- # productCode, productName, largest_order_quantity
-- S12_4675, 1969 Dodge Charger, 97
-- S18_3278, 1969 Dodge Super Bee, 90
-- S700_2466, America West Airlines B757-200, 85
-- S700_3167, F/A 18 Hornet 1/72, 77
-- S12_3990, 1970 Plymouth Hemi Cuda, 77
-- S24_3856, 1956 Porsche 356A Coupe, 76
-- S18_1749, 1917 Grand Touring Sedan, 76
-- S24_2766, 1949 Jaguar XK 120, 76
-- S24_2300, 1962 Volkswagen Microbus, 70
-- S10_4698, 2003 Harley-Davidson Eagle Drag Bike, 66
```

### 3. Rewrite the above query using CTE. Then comment on the advantages of the CTE approach relative to the subquery approach, paying attention to the execution speed of the two queries as one aspect of difference.

```
WITH largest_orders as (
    SELECT productcode, max(quantityOrdered) AS largest_order_quantity
    FROM orderdetails
    GROUP BY productcode
)
SELECT productCode, productName, largest_order_quantity
FROM products JOIN largest_orders USING (productcode)
ORDER BY largest_order_quantity desc;

-- 109 row(s) returned

# productCode, productName, largest_order_quantity
-- S12_4675, 1969 Dodge Charger, 97
-- S18_3278, 1969 Dodge Super Bee, 90
-- S700_2466, America West Airlines B757-200, 85
-- S700_3167, F/A 18 Hornet 1/72, 77
-- S12_3990, 1970 Plymouth Hemi Cuda, 77
-- S24_3856, 1956 Porsche 356A Coupe, 76
-- S18_1749, 1917 Grand Touring Sedan, 76
-- S24_2766, 1949 Jaguar XK 120, 76
-- S24_2300, 1962 Volkswagen Microbus, 70
-- S10_4698, 2003 Harley-Davidson Eagle Drag Bike, 66
```

-- The CTE approach is more readable and is also more computationally efficient since it does not need to compute largest\_order\_quanity over and over again for the same product.

### 4. Use CTE to find out low performing products with each product line, where a product's performance defined as the total sales of a product (a single sale amount is calculated from order details as quantityOrdered\*priceEach), and low performance is defined as below 50% of average total sales across all products in a product line. Display a product's code, name, line, total sales (as `total_sales`), and avg\_sales. Round avg\_sales to two decimal places.

> tip: consider using chained CTEs, first computing each product's total sales, then average total sales.

```
WITH product_sales as (
    SELECT productcode, sum(quantityOrdered*priceEach) AS sales
    FROM orderdetails
    GROUP BY productcode
),
average_sales AS (
    SELECT productline, round(avg(sales),2) AS avg_sales
    FROM products join product_sales USING (productcode)
    GROUP BY productline
)
SELECT productCode, productName, productLine, sales, avg_sales
FROM products JOIN average_sales USING(productLine)
JOIN product_sales USING(productcode)
WHERE sales < 0.5*avg_sales;

-- 9 row(s) returned

-- # productCode, productName, productLine, sales, avg_sales
-- S18_4933, 1957 Ford Thunderbird, Classic Cars, 50101.57, 104160.07
-- S24_1444, 1970 Dodge Coronet, Classic Cars, 50255.45, 104160.07
-- S24_1628, 1966 Shelby Cobra 427 S/C, Classic Cars, 42015.54, 104160.07
-- S24_1937, 1939 Chevrolet Deluxe Coupe, Vintage Cars, 28052.94, 74898.32
-- S24_2840, 1958 Chevy Corvette Limited Edition, Classic Cars, 31627.96, 104160.07
-- S24_2972, 1982 Lamborghini Diablo, Classic Cars, 30972.87, 104160.07
-- S24_3969, 1936 Mercedes Benz 500k Roadster, Vintage Cars, 29763.39, 74898.32
-- S32_2206, 1982 Ducati 996 R, Motorcycles, 33268.76, 86263.55
-- S32_2509, 1954 Greyhound Scenicruiser, Trucks and Buses, 46519.05, 93101.23

### 5. Find each payment's amount along with the paying customer's cumulative payment up to this date, displaying customer number, payment date, payment amount, and customer_cum_amount, ordering results by customer number and payment date.

```sql
SELECT customerNumber, paymentDate, amount, SUM(amount) OVER (partition by customerNumber ORDER BY paymentDate) AS customer_cum_amount
FROM payments
ORDER BY customerNumber, paymentDate;

-- 273 row(s) returned

-- # customerNumber, paymentDate, amount, customer_cum_amount
-- 103, 2003-06-05 00:00:00, 14571.44, 14571.44
-- 103, 2004-10-19 00:00:00, 6066.78, 20638.22
-- 103, 2004-12-18 00:00:00, 1676.14, 22314.36
-- 112, 2003-06-06 00:00:00, 32641.98, 32641.98
-- 112, 2004-08-20 00:00:00, 33347.88, 65989.86
-- 112, 2004-12-17 00:00:00, 14191.12, 80180.98
-- 114, 2003-05-20 00:00:00, 45864.03, 45864.03
-- 114, 2003-05-31 00:00:00, 7565.08, 53429.11
-- 114, 2004-03-10 00:00:00, 44894.74, 98323.85
-- 114, 2004-12-15 00:00:00, 82261.22, 180585.07
```

### 6. (monthly order cumulative average) Find each order's total amount (computing the total amount from orderDetails), along with the same month's average order amount, showing each order's number, date, customer number, order total, and monthly cumulative average (as `cumulative_average`)

> tip: to obtain the year-month, you may use `left(orderDate, 7)`, treating orderDate as a string.

```
WITH order_totals AS (
    SELECT ordernumber, SUM(quantityOrdered*priceeach) AS order_total
    FROM orderdetails
    GROUP BY ordernumber
)
SELECT orderNumber, orderDate, customerNumber, order_total,
AVG(order_total) OVER (PARTITION BY left(orderDate, 7) ORDER BY orderDate, orderNumber) AS cumulative_average
FROM orders JOIN order_totals USING (ordernumber);

-- 326 row(s) returned

-- # orderNumber, orderDate, customerNumber, order_total, cumulative_average
-- 10100, 2003-01-06 00:00:00, 363, 10223.83, 10223.830000
-- 10101, 2003-01-09 00:00:00, 128, 10549.01, 10386.420000
-- 10102, 2003-01-10 00:00:00, 181, 5494.78, 8755.873333
-- 10103, 2003-01-29 00:00:00, 121, 50218.95, 19121.642500
-- 10104, 2003-01-31 00:00:00, 141, 40206.20, 23338.554000
-- 10105, 2003-02-11 00:00:00, 145, 53959.21, 53959.210000
-- 10106, 2003-02-17 00:00:00, 278, 52151.81, 53055.510000
-- 10107, 2003-02-24 00:00:00, 131, 22292.62, 42801.213333
-- 10108, 2003-03-03 00:00:00, 385, 51001.22, 51001.220000
-- 10109, 2003-03-10 00:00:00, 486, 25833.14, 38417.180000
```

### 7. (top 10 orders) Find the top 10 order of all time, displaying the order's number, total amount (as `order_total`), and rank (as `order_rank`).

> tip: since order total must be computed from order details, consider chained CTEs that compute the order totals first, then rank them, then select top 10.

```
WITH order_totals AS (
    SELECT ordernumber, SUM(quantityOrdered*priceeach) AS order_total
    FROM orderdetails
    GROUP BY ordernumber
),
order_ranks AS (
    SELECT orderNumber, order_total, RANK() OVER (ORDER BY order_total DESC) AS order_rank
    FROM order_totals
)
SELECT *
FROM order_ranks
WHERE order_rank<=10;

-- 10 row(s) returned

-- # orderNumber, order_total, order_rank
-- 10165, 67392.85, 1
-- 10287, 61402.00, 2
-- 10310, 61234.67, 3
-- 10212, 59830.55, 4
-- 10207, 59265.14, 5
-- 10127, 58841.35, 6
-- 10204, 58793.53, 7
-- 10126, 57131.92, 8
-- 10222, 56822.65, 9
-- 10142, 56052.56, 10
```

## Module 03: Overview

This module marks the final installment of our SQL query series and introduces three advanced—but powerful—tools for writing more expressive and efficient queries: **subqueries**, **Common Table Expressions (CTEs)**, and **window functions**. These techniques are essential for handling complex data manipulation tasks that go beyond basic filtering and aggregation.

### Learning Objectives

* Understand and apply **subqueries** to filter/augment data.
* Write and use **Common Table Expressions** (**CTEs**) to modularize SQL logic and build layered queries.
* Use **window functions** to compute rankings, cumulative totals, moving averages, and row-level comparisons.
* Differentiate between subqueries, JOINs, and CTEs and determine when each approach is appropriate.

### To-Do This Module

* Watch lecture videos and related supportive videos
* Complete **knowledge checks** associated with each video (if available)
* Complete the **lab 3** for the module (you can do a problem set after each lecture video)
* Complete the **homework 2**.
* Complete **Quiz 1**

Module Details (built in browser, hidden in app)

## Module 04: Overview

In this module, you’ll be introduced to the Entity Relationship (ER) Diagram—a powerful visual tool for data modeling. We’ll explore its key components and best practices for designing data structures. ER diagrams will help you understand, communicate, and organize data more effectively, laying the foundation for building well-structured relational databases. Together with the next module, this will provide a complete view of how to optimally structure your data for storage and analysis.

### Learning Objectives

* Describe the purpose and key components of Entity-Relationship Diagrams (ERDs)
* Identify and define different types of attributes and apply best practices in modeling them
* Design ER diagrams with correct use of primary keys, foreign keys, cardinality
* Apply general guidelines to create clear, accurate, and practical ERDs based on real-world scenarios.

### To-Do This Module

* Watch lecture videos and related supportive content
* Complete **knowledge checks** associated with each video (if available)
* Complete the **lab 4**for the module
* You may complete the **part of homework 3** covered in this module instead of waiting till Module 5 to complete it.

Module Details (built in browser, hidden in app)

-- -----------------------------------------------------

SELECT terms_id, COUNT( * ) AS no_invoices

SELECT invoice_date, COUNT( * ) AS no_invoices, AVG( invoice_total ) AS avg_invoice_total

having no_invoices > 1

-- ##5:  Using the vendors table, display the vendor’s name, phone, and area code.

SELECT vendor_name, vendor_phone, SUBSTR(vendor_phone,2,3) AS area_code

-- # vendor_name, vendor_phone, area_code

when 2 then "due in 20 days"

# MABA 6321 Homework 1 - SQL (solution) ## Part 1: Short Answers 1. Explain the following concepts in one or two sentences. * **DBMS**: refers to a general-purpose software system that facilitates the processes of defining, creating, using and maintaining databases * **Primary Key**: A primary key is a column or a set of columns in a database table that uniquely identifies each row in that table. * **Foreign Key**: is a field (or a set of fields) in one table that refers to the primary key in another table. It creates a relationship between two tables and enforces referential integrity. * **DML**: are SQL commands that maintain and query a database * **DDL**: are SQL commands that define a database, including creating, altering, and dropping tables and establishing constraints * **Outer JOIN**: is a type of SQL join that returns matched rows from two tables along with the unmatched rows from one or both tables, filling in missing values with NULLs. ## Part 2: Hands On ``` -- ### 1. # Syllabus

## **Strategic Marketing MKTG 6088 S a-term 25**

### Course Description (8 weeks)

This course is designed to enhance your understanding of strategic marketing and build your skills as a strategic marketing leader. The focus is to help you develop and execute marketing strategies that will create and build competitive advantage and deliver strong financial results. The course assumes you know the basics of marketing; the class is focused on extending that knowledge and helping you apply marketing concepts and principles in a dynamic market as a general manager or senior marketing executive.

We will cover topic such as segmentation, positioning and focus strategies, sustainable competitive advantage, identifying and exploring growth opportunities, managing customer relationships, and aligning the organization to changing market requirements. The course is case based and focuses on applied problem solving in case examples.

### Course Objectives

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

1. Explain and defend the role of marketing within the organization.
2. Develop tactical options for any given set of market conditions.
3. Critically examine marketing strategy.
4. Calculate and defend the costs of different marketing strategies.
5. Implement marketing programs.
6. Justify marketing decisions.

### Course Evaluation Schedule

Written Case Reports  (6 @ 25 points)                       150 points

Class Participation                                                         75 points

CMO Strategy Reflection Paper                                    50 points

Total Points Available                                                   275 points

Final grades will be awarded using the UM A/F scale with pluses and minuses.

### Text

Case Pack HBS (see Library Course Page)

### Expectations

1. Participants are adult members of society with experience that informs discussion.
2. Participants have expectations for this course that they will pursue and defend.
3. Participants will be prepared to participate, having read the material assigned, and having identified questions and issues to discuss. You are expected to manage and access your University of Minnesota communicationson a regular and frequent basis.
4. You should maintain a copy of all submitted assignments and work.
5. Participants are consumers with a vast—though possibly unconscious—awareness of marketing tactics and strategies.
6. Participants are members of a civil society who know how to debate, discuss, and disagree without resorting to personal attack or sophomoric behavior.

### Ground Rules

There will be no incompletes given. Late work is not accepted, unless prior arrangements have been made, *(extraordinary circumstances)*

Participation is a quality dimension not a volume or frequency score. Make sure you turn in all cases and assignments. Everyone is expected to participate in class discussions.

Grades are on a scale of 1–25. Your instructor will use the following criteria to evaluate your papers:

* The level of strategic analysis and critical thinking demonstrated in your response.
* The completeness of your answers to all questions posed.
* The quality of the justifications used to support your claims and recommendations.

**Write clearly. Be concise. Use facts to support your points.**

Discuss what you think are the most important strategic issues in Marketing - what is most important for success? Use or leverage any material/concepts from class materials,  focus on what are key implications for strategic marketing. Pick some key concepts/issues and learnings explored in class and discuss how those impact the application of strategic marketing principles. Try to uncover themes or issues and connect to how they relate to the practical application of strategic marketing principals/impact on tactical execution, how the insights could help and why.  Comment on what you think is important or critical in order to make effective and impactful strategic decisions. You can comment on current state or future state of strategic marketing, what concepts impacted your thinking?

## Case Analysis Write Up

Each week, you will write a short paper that answers key questions about the cases you review. This week, your paper should answer the following questions about the Callaway case:

1. Define key elements in Callaway’s Strategy (1988–1997),
2. What were the biggest drivers of success? Explain why the strategy was successful.
3. Is the strategy still relevant? Why or why not? What, if any, changes to the strategy would you recommend?

Answer the questions in no more than three typed pages. Save as Case name followed by your name .doc (for example, callwayhopkins.doc). You can collaborate and discuss the case with your classmates but must each turn in a separate paper.

Grades are on a scale of 1–25. Your instructor will use the following criteria to evaluate your papers:

* The level of strategic analysis and critical thinking demonstrated in your response.
* The completeness of your answers to all questions posed.
* The quality of the justifications used to support your claims and recommendations.

Write clearly. Be concise. Use facts to support your points.

## [dhopkins.jpg](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/116205/files/7193122/download?wrap=1 "dhopkins.jpg")Meet Your Course Team

### Dave Hopkins

#### **dhopkins.jpg**

Prior to joining Carlson School, David had spent more than 20 years in leadership positions in consulting and industry. He has been at CSOM 15 years and is Managing Director of the Brand Enterprise he teaches MBA and executive courses in Marketing Management, Marketing Strategy, Digital Marketing, and Brand Management.

He is Principal at Windshift consulting and strategic advisory. Prior, he was the managing director/CSO for U.S. operations at MRM Worldgroup, a global marketing services firm. For six years, David was the national practice leader in enterprise strategy and operations for Grant Thornton LLP, where he helped companies achieve balance between top-line growth and competitiveness. Previously, he served as the operations and marketing director for Aegis Consulting and as a senior consultant for Saatchi and Saatchi. He was also a founder of Minute Clinic/Quick Med, an industry-changing health care concept.

Mr. Hopkins has had several articles published and is sought after as an industry/subject matter expert for regional and national print and broadcast media.

### Next step: Read the course syllabus

The [course syllabus](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/116205/assignments/syllabus "Course Syllabus") will provide you with the course schedule, course objectives, explanations of assignments and assessments, grading policies, and instructor contact information. Please read it carefully. You should have a deep familiarity with the schedule and process of the course.

#### Make-up for Missed Attendance, Assignments, & Exams

Please review the [university policy on make-up work](https://policy.umn.edu/education/makeupwork).

### Carlson Course Grading Policy

Carlson School uses a grading policy based upon a class median aggregate GPA. Learn more about the [Carlson Course Grading Policy](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_graduate_grading).

### Carlson & University Policies

#### Student Academic Misconduct and Scholastic Dishonesty

The Carlson School defines academic misconduct as any act by a student that misrepresents the student's own academic work or that compromises the academic work of another. Scholastic misconduct includes (but is not limited to) cheating on assignments or examinations, plagiarizing, i.e., misrepresenting as one's own work any work done by another, submitting the same paper, or substantially similar papers, to meet the requirement of more than one course without the approval and consent of the instructors concerned, or sabotaging another's work. Within this general definition, however, instructors determine what constitutes academic misconduct in the courses they teach. Students found guilty of academic misconduct face penalties ranging from lowering of the course grade or awarding a grade of F or N for the entire course, to suspension from the University.

Review the [Student Conduct Code](https://z.umn.edu/policy-carlson_student_conduct_code) and [Student Conduct and Academic Integrity website](https://z.umn.edu/student_conduct_academic_integrity).

If you are interested in learning more about how to cite sources and avoid plagiarism, U of M libraries offers online [tutorials and tools related to citations](https://z.umn.edu/research_citation_tools). You can also visit the [Center for Writing](https://z.umn.edu/center_for_writing) for additional assistance.

#### Accommodations for Students with Disabilities

The University of Minnesota is committed to providing all students equal access to learning opportunities. 
The Disability Resource Center (DRC) is the campus office that works with students who have disabilities to provide and/or arrange reasonable accommodations. Students registered with the DRC, who have a letter requesting accommodations, are encouraged to contact the instructor early in the semester. Students who have, or think they may have, a disability (e.g. psychiatric, attention, learning, vision, hearing, physical, or systemic), are invited to contact the DRC for a confidential discussion at 612-626-1333 (V/TTY) or at [drc@umn.edu](mailto:drc@umn.edu). Additional information is available on the [Disability Resource Center website](https://z.umn.edu/disability_resource_center).

#### Title IX

[Title IX](https://z.umn.edu/title_ix_process) prohibits sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, sexual assault, stalking, and relationship violence, in education.

#### Students with Mental Health and Stress Management

As a student you may experience a range of issues that can cause barriers to learning, such as strained relationships, increased anxiety, alcohol/drug problems, feeling down, difficulty concentrating and/or lack of motivation. These mental health concerns or stressful events may lead to diminished academic performance or reduce a student's ability to participate in daily activities. University of Minnesota services are available to assist you with addressing these and other concerns you may be experiencing. Learn more about the broad range of confidential [mental health services](https://z.umn.edu/mental_health_services) available on campus.

#### Student Writing Support

As a student, you may experience challenges in your writing. The University of Minnesota has a [student writing support resource](https://z.umn.edu/student_writing_support) to help with your writing.

text:
President Reagan has 5 different AIMs in his Challenger speech.

Identify each of the 5 Audiences, Intentions, and Messages.

**A****UDIENCE:** *Who* are you speaking to?

**I****NTENT:** *How* do you want them to feel and think?

**M****ESSAGE:** *What* is the takeaway?

Here is a document outlining everything said in the speech broken down into the separate AIMs to help.

[1.6 Reagan Speech Exercise.docx](https://canvas.umn.edu/courses/486812/files/48715925/download?wrap=1 "1.6 Reagan Speech Exercise.docx")

Click below to start working on the exercise. Although Canvas calls it a "quiz" and Professor Vlad will see your responses, this is NOT graded.
